bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 17 (Tuesday, January 30, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. OGLES:H.R. 7143.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section VIII of the United States ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:To withdraw the OCC's/Fed's/FDIC's proposed rule (88 Fed.Reg. 64028) on regulatory capital requirements[Page H317]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

summary.text:
Stop Basel Endgame Act

This bill requires the withdrawal of the proposed rule titled Regulatory Capital Rule: Large Banking Organizations and Banking Organizations with Significant Trading Activity. The proposed rule revises bank capital requirements and calculations, including by requiring banks to replace their use of internal credit risk models with a standardized approach generally in line with international standards set by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. The rule was proposed on September 18, 2023, by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

bill.title: Stop Basel Endgame Act

item.title: To require the heads of certain agencies to withdraw a proposed rule relating to capital requirements applicable to large banking organizations and banking organizations with significant trading activity, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
